review_title: Good foot in the door management position
pros: Flexible scheduling: McDonald's is open 24/7, so employees can work around their school or other commitments. Career growth: McDonald's offers a variety of career opportunities and provides training and development programs for its employees. Teamwork and camaraderie: McDonald's is a fast-paced environment that requires employees to work together as a team. Competitive pay and benefits: McDonald's offers competitive pay and benefits packages, including health insurance, 401(k) plans, and paid time off. Community involvement: McDonald's is actively involved in the communities it serves, and employees can get involved in volunteer and community service activities. Discounts: McDonald's employees are eligible for discounts on food and merchandise, as well as discounts on other products and services. Good for students: McDonald's is a good place for students to gain work experience. Diversity and Inclusion: McDonald's values diversity and inclusion and is committed to creating a welcoming environment for all employees.
cons: Fast-paced and physically demanding work: McDonald's is a fast food restaurant and the work can be physically demanding, including standing for long periods of time, lifting heavy bags of food, and working quickly during busy periods. Limited room for advancement: Advancement opportunities may be limited for employees who wish to move up the career ladder. Low pay: The pay may be low, especially for entry-level positions. High employee turnover: McDonald's has a high employee turnover rate. Stressful work environment: McDonald's can be a stressful work environment, particularly during busy periods, which can be demanding and fast-paced. Limited benefits: Benefits may be limited, particularly for part-time or entry-level employees. Limited schedule flexibility: Despite flexible scheduling, working at odd hours, weekends and holidays are a norm in Mcdonalds. Shortage of staff: McDonald's may be short-staffed during certain periods, which can lead to employees being required to work overtime or extra shifts.

review_title: A good starting job - Will test you
pros: Want to learn on the fast lane? This is the job to do all the basic things. Take orders, make orders, clean, and serve. You can learn to do it all in a small time frame. Time is always of the essence when you work here. If you do not want to get shouted at, you learn quickly to manage your time efficiently. Flexible work hours and they are always hiring.
cons: Location dependent, people dependent. Same with any other place. This means your experiences may differ when it comes to this company. You could get the best team to work with, but an apocalypse of customer rushes. Your managers can be good or terrible. Personally, I have had all these experiences at one point or another. It comes with the territory but it can help build character.

review_title: Good first time job, flexible. Questionable management
pros: The pros of the job is that it is flexible, as you're on a zero hour contract. So changes to your schedule can be made easier than other jobs. The pay also isn't bad, I get paid more than some other jobs working in hospitality so it is competitive. I'd say it's a great first job to see how working in a team is like, and build real life work experience.
cons: Management can be questionable, depending on store to store and shift to shift. But generally you're not supported in learning about how holiday pay/technical side works. And with the training, people tend to have their own ways of doing stuff which isn't actually protocol, so it's hard to find out the correct way of doing something. At times you may have no break when it is busy or a really early or late break.

job_title: Crew Member in Rancho Cucamonga, CA
pros: Little to no training needed-job is insanely easy and repetitive. Management where I worked was alright, but that really is based on luck.
cons: You learn no useful personal skills-all you do is serve the same food all day. Too busy-if you have managers who suck at scheduling workers, be prepared to deal with angry customers who have waited 30 mins for their food. People who buy from fast food chains also tend to be entitled-some can be real Karens, but that is expected for all retail and fast food jobs. Many of your co-workers will be kids right out of high school and don't expect them to be good at their job-expect stupid but entertaining gossip sessions. Oh and you can work for a year to be promoted to a manager to earn only ONE more dollar per hour. Good job to take for the experience, but never a choice for a long-term career.

review_title: For part time, it is for experience and quick cash paycheck.
pros:
Depending on the location, the store I worked at had a lot of young college students. We all wanted to make things work out and treat each other with respect. Management was clear and straightforward. They were all nice and understanding. (Sympathy is hard to come by nowadays). Flexible schedule setting.

There is a lot of social benefits and friendships built. We were like family. It was a chill work relationship. Immigrants and American-born. Lots of translators. Quite a diverse team when I was working at the time. (Vietnamese, Chinese, Taiwanese, Filipino, Korean, Hispanic, Caucasian)
cons:
Just like 9-5, clock in, clock out. Commit to your word. The active manager determines lunch breaks. (Given when there is downtime or rush hour. Cannot select when to take breaks based on convenience).

As for promotions, it really depends on how many people work. Policy was that there cannot be too many managers. (We had a total of 7-10). But the pay raise is 25 cents to 75 cents. Possibly $5.00 difference (depending on how many years you worked for, and if you can be trusted).

Most management is good. However, there were a few bad apples with ego.
